dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, a lot of people these days, I think, they hear about AIDS and they kind of, uh, assume that fight's almost over, right? Like, we've basically won.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, a lot of people these days, I think, they hear about A I D S and they kind of, uh, assume that fight's almost over, right? Like, we've basically won.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And yet, despite the remarkable progress made during the last three decades or perhaps because of it we must avoid the temptation to declare the fight against AIDS almost over.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's definitely a common perception, isn't it? But, um, the article we read really pushes back on that, saying we've got this false sense of accomplishment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's definitely a common perception, isn't it? But, um, the article we read really pushes back on that, saying we've got this false sense of accomplishment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the transition from a goal to a target, combined with steep declines in AIDS-related deaths, has lulled us into a false sense of accomplishment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It's like, we *have* made incredible progress, especially since the 80s, thanks to things like the Millennium Development Goals. They really prioritized HIV.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It's like, we have made incredible progress, especially since the eighty seconds, thanks to things like the Millennium Development Goals. They really prioritized H I V.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the turn of the century, many of the advances against HIV were enabled by the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), a 15-year policy roadmap that made reducing the spread of the virus a top priority.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which was huge, right? Like, unprecedented expansion of services, particularly in developing countries. But then, when the SDGs took over in 2020, ending AIDS kinda became, well, just one of 169 targets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which was huge, right? Like, unprecedented expansion of services, particularly in developing countries. But then, when the S D Gs took over in twenty twenty, ending A I D S kinda became, well, just one of one hundred sixty nine targets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: when the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) succeeded the MDGs in 2015, ending AIDS was no longer a standalone goal. Rather, further progress had become one of 169 targets that the SDGs are supposed to achieve by 2030.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, from a *goal* to just a *target*. And that, combined with the real decline in deaths, has sort of lulled us, hasn't it? We think it's almost done.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, from a goal to just a target. And that, combined with the real decline in deaths, has sort of lulled us, hasn't it? We think it's almost done.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the transition from a goal to a target, combined with steep declines in AIDS-related deaths, has lulled us into a false sense of accomplishment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unfortunately, nothing could be further from the truth. It's such a complex issue. We focus a lot on the biomedical side – which is vital, don't get me wrong – but it's not enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unfortunately, nothing could be further from the truth. It's such a complex issue. We focus a lot on the biomedical side - which is vital, don't get me wrong - but it's not enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, nothing could be further from the truth. HIV is a complex issue. Biomedical responses are vital to disease control, but if people cannot access medicine or preventive services, even the best-designed initiatives will fail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's not. Because if people can't *access* the medicine or prevention, even the best initiatives fail. And often, those obstacles aren't even about healthcare, are they? It's about social and political stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's not. Because if people can't access the medicine or prevention, even the best initiatives fail. And often, those obstacles aren't even about healthcare, are they? It's about social and political stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whats more, the obstacles to treatment often have nothing to do with health care, but rather, are tied to political, economic, and social marginalization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Think about gender inequality, for instance. How do you lower infection rates if women can't even make decisions about when, or with whom, they have sex? It's just... [sighs] a massive barrier.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Think about gender inequality, for instance. How do you lower infection rates if women can't even make decisions about when, or with whom, they have sex? It's just a massive barrier.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, it can be difficult to lower rates of infection in countries where gender inequality prevents women from making decisions about when, where, and even with whom they have sex.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And while it's true that, in many places, HIV is now a chronic, manageable disease – and that's absolutely worth celebrating, uh – millions still don't know their status. Or can't get support when they test positive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And while it's true that, in many places, H I V is now a chronic, manageable disease - and that's absolutely worth celebrating, uh - millions still don't know their status. Or can't get support when they test positive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: in many parts of the world, HIV is now considered a chronic disease manageable with medication and lifestyle changes; that fact alone is worthy of celebration. Nonetheless, millions of people still do not know their HIV status or cannot get the support they need when they test positive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, we have to close those gaps. And the article really stresses integrating the HIV fight into broader sustainable development planning. Like, linking it to social protection, food security, gender-based violence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we have to close those gaps. And the article really stresses integrating the H I V fight into broader sustainable development planning. Like, linking it to social protection, food security, gender-based violence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When governments work to implement the SDGs in areas like social protection, food security, and gender-based violence, HIV responses must also be part of their plans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because those issues are often what predispose people to infection in the first place, like poverty or, uh, gender bias. We saw that shocking example from Tanzania last month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because those issues are often what predispose people to infection in the first place, like poverty or, uh, gender bias. We saw that shocking example from Tanzania last month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Only by linking HIV strategies to the issues that predispose people to infection such as poverty, education, and gender bias can we hope for a future free from AIDS for everyone, everywhere. We have a long way to go before that happens. For example, just last month in Tanzania...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the LGBT community being forced into hiding? Absolutely horrific. And when those groups are on the frontlines of HIV prevention, any threat to their human rights is a direct threat to the HIV response.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the L G B T community being forced into hiding? Absolutely horrific. And when those groups are on the frontlines of H I V prevention, any threat to their human rights is a direct threat to the H I V response.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With LGBT groups on the frontlines of Tanzanias HIV-prevention efforts, any threat to their members human rights is also a threat to the HIV response.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's not just Tanzania either, is it? The report mentioned the Middle East and North Africa, where forced sex, both inside and outside marriage, is still so pervasive. That dramatically increases risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not just Tanzania either, is it? The report mentioned the Middle East and North Africa, where forced sex, both inside and outside marriage, is still so pervasive. That dramatically increases risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nor is Tanzania the exception. On the contrary, as a recent report by my organization highlights, the situation is especially dire in the Middle East and North Africa, where forced sex within and outside of marriage is pervasive. These coercive and often violent encounters increase womens risk of exposure to HIV.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Activists have always known this isn't just a medical problem. It's about social, cultural, economic, legal challenges. We can't forget that inclusive approach.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Activists have always known this isn't just a medical problem. It's about social, cultural, economic, legal challenges. We can't forget that inclusive approach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Those on the frontlines of the AIDS response have always recognized that the disease cannot be overcome in isolation; rather, it must be addressed through an interconnected set of social, cultural, economic, and legal challenges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, we can't. The SDG mantra is "leave no one behind," but right now, many of those most vulnerable to HIV, um, are absolutely being forgotten.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, we can't. The S D G mantra is "leave no one behind," but right now, many of those most vulnerable to H I V, um, are absolutely being forgotten.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The mantra of the SDGs is leave no one behind. At the moment, however, many of those most vulnerable to HIV are being forgotten and will be left behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. The infection rates are highest among the poor and marginalized. So, until we meet those broader SDGs, ending HIV is going to remain, well, pretty elusive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. The infection rates are highest among the poor and marginalized. So, until we meet those broader S D Gs, ending H I V is going to remain, well, pretty elusive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, HIV infection rates are highest among the poor and socially marginalized, underscoring the fact that as long as the SDGs are unmet, the goal of ending the scourge of HIV/AIDS will remain elusive.
